Award.AwardTitle: Label-free, chemiresistive, paper microfluidic nanobiosensor array for multiplexed detection

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Tsutsui, Hideaki
Proposal No: 1606181

This project proposes to develop a paper-based molecular sensing platform. The primary advantages are its low cost and ease of use. The proposed work is expected to broadly expand the capability and applications of paper-based sensors for a variety of fields, such as medical, agricultural, and environmental testing and diagnosis.



Paper-based microfluidic devices have recently emerged as promising sensing platforms for serving the diagnostic needs in many sectors of society. Advantages of paper-based microfluidic sensors include fast detection, ease of fabrication and use, minimal instrument requirements, lightweight, portability, and low cost. However, its widespread use beyond research laboratories has been hampered because of a lack of highly sensitive detection methods that can be easily implemented on a paper substrate. The overall goal of this project is to develop a label-free, highly sensitive, chemiresistive nanosensor platform. This goal will be achieved through a series of research tasks: 1) development of an ultrasensitive carbon nanotube chemiresistive biosensor on paper; 2) development of an effective fluid handling technology; and 3) integration and demonstration of label-free, multiplexed detection of cardiac biomarkers as model antigens. Intellectual merits include a highly sensitive sensing element made of semiconducting single-walled carbon nanotubes and technological innovations of microfluidic transport, which collectively enable the proposed nanosensor. Broader impact of the research program is expansion of the capability and applications of the paper-based microfluidic-facilitated biosensors. In particular, the proposed label-free chemiresistive biosensor array is expected to be highly sensitive, facile, and economical. It is also expected to be readily applicable to the multiplexed detection of analytes in a variety of complex fluid matrices such as food, water, plants, and body fluids. In conjunction with research activities, this project will develop and integrate several outreach and educational activities, including new curricula development on paper-based microfluidic biosensors, research training of both undergraduate and graduate students, particularly underrepresented minorities and women, and outreach efforts to engage K-12 teachers and students of the Inland Empire region of California.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a label-free, chemiresistive paper-based microfluidic nanobiosensor that enables facile, sensitive, and quantitative detection of multiple molecular targets in complex fluid matrices. This goal was collectively achieved through a series of research and development as summarized below. In addition, throughout this project period, we trained and worked with graduate students and undergraduate students, including those who were in the underrepresented groups in the STEM field. We also engaged K-12 educators and middle and high school students by hosting multiple hands-on workshops at regional educational conferences and STEM outreach events.


1. We developed two methods of successfully patterning single walled carbon nanotube (SWNT) electrodes on paper substrates. The first approach is depositing SWNTs through solid-ink (e.g. wax) patterns printed with a commercial solid ink printer using vacuum filtration. The second method is by directly printing SWNTs dissolved in a solvent using a professional inkjet printer. The latter, in particular, provided precision and resolution to fabricate well-defined SWNT sensor arrays.


2. We designed and fabricated three generations of SWNT chemiresistive paper-based biosensors. The first generation featured an SWNT electrode deposited by the vacuum filtration on a strip of paper. The electrode was functionalized with anti-human serum albumin (anti-HSA) for specific detection of HSA in a phosphate buffer (PB). The device demonstrated successful detection of HSA in PB. This work was published in Biosensors and Bioelectronics (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bios.2018.09.041).


3. The second-generation device used the same senor strip as the previous generation, but featured a new fluid handling layer to achieve automated and timed delivery of the sample solution and a wash buffer. This was achieved by paper-based microfluidic design featuring laser-etched grooves that expedited sample delivery to the SWNT sensor surface, followed by delayed delivery of the wash buffer, allowing a sample incubation period required for detection. We successfully detected HSA in PB, artificial urine (AU), and artificial saliva (AS).


4. The third-generation device featured an array of five inkjet-printed SWNT sensors connected to a central sample inlet. The sample solution added to the inlet was equally split into the five connecting channels and arrived at the sensors functionalized with different antibodies (anti-HSA and anti-human immunoglobulin G (HIgG)). This design successfully allowed simultaneous detections of multiple targets (HSA and HIgG in this specific example) on a single device. We achieved quantitative detections of HSA and HIgG in PB, AU, AS, and diluted human serum and blood. This multilayer device design and fabrication was also effectively implemented using an origami paper folding technique for ease of assembly and precise alignment. This work was published in Biosensors and Bioelectronics (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bios.2020.112721) and filed for an international patent.


Last Modified: 10/28/2020
Modified by: Hideaki Tsutsui
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to develop a label-free, chemiresistive paper-based microfluidic nanobiosensor that enables facile, sensitive, and quantitative detection of multiple molecular targets in complex fluid matrices. This goal was collectively achieved through a series of research and development as summarized below. In addition, throughout this project period, we trained and worked with graduate students and undergraduate students, including those who were in the underrepresented groups in the STEM field. We also engaged K-12 educators and middle and high school students by hosting multiple hands-on workshops at regional educational conferences and STEM outreach events. 1. We developed two methods of successfully patterning single walled carbon nanotube (SWNT) electrodes on paper substrates. The first approach is depositing SWNTs through solid-ink (e.g. wax) patterns printed with a commercial solid ink printer using vacuum filtration. The second method is by directly printing SWNTs dissolved in a solvent using a professional inkjet printer. The latter, in particular, provided precision and resolution to fabricate well-defined SWNT sensor arrays. 2. We designed and fabricated three generations of SWNT chemiresistive paper-based biosensors. The first generation featured an SWNT electrode deposited by the vacuum filtration on a strip of paper. The electrode was functionalized with anti-human serum albumin (anti-HSA) for specific detection of HSA in a phosphate buffer (PB). The device demonstrated successful detection of HSA in PB. This work was published in Biosensors and Bioelectronics (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bios.2018.09.041). 3. The second-generation device used the same senor strip as the previous generation, but featured a new fluid handling layer to achieve automated and timed delivery of the sample solution and a wash buffer. This was achieved by paper-based microfluidic design featuring laser-etched grooves that expedited sample delivery to the SWNT sensor surface, followed by delayed delivery of the wash buffer, allowing a sample incubation period required for detection. We successfully detected HSA in PB, artificial urine (AU), and artificial saliva (AS). 4. The third-generation device featured an array of five inkjet-printed SWNT sensors connected to a central sample inlet. The sample solution added to the inlet was equally split into the five connecting channels and arrived at the sensors functionalized with different antibodies (anti-HSA and anti-human immunoglobulin G (HIgG)). This design successfully allowed simultaneous detections of multiple targets (HSA and HIgG in this specific example) on a single device. We achieved quantitative detections of HSA and HIgG in PB, AU, AS, and diluted human serum and blood. This multilayer device design and fabrication was also effectively implemented using an origami paper folding technique for ease of assembly and precise alignment. This work was published in Biosensors and Bioelectronics (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bios.2020.112721) and filed for an international patent. Last Modified: 10/28/2020 Submitted by: Hideaki Tsutsui
